channel.title: [Maths] Exam question help
channel.description:
I just finished my last IGCSE maths paper (4H) yesterday, I found it much easier then I was expecting and I think I may just get an A. But the last question I spent over half an hour on, and still was unable to complete it. I remember it exactly, so can somebody put me out of my misery and tell me what I should have done.
Here is the question:
Simplify this equation: [IMG]http://i125.photobucket.com/albums/p80/davidude36/problem1234.jpg[/img]
Thanks for anyone who can tell me what I should have done!

@Stork wrote:

The numerator is the difference of two squares:

In the denominator, you can take out a factor of x, leaving you with:

And then you can cancel, simplifying the equation.
